Class Move

java.lang.Object
com.github.bhlangonijr.chesslib.move.Move
All Implemented Interfaces:
BoardEvent
public class Move extends Object implements BoardEvent
The definition of a chess move, that is, a piece movement from its starting square (the origin square) to a destination square. Optionally, the move could specify a promotion piece used to replace a pawn in case of promotion.

The move is also a BoardEvent, and hence it can be passed to the observers of the BoardEventType.ON_MOVE events, emitted when a move is executed on a board.

    Move(String move, Side side)
    Creates a new move using a string representing the coordinates of the origin and destination squares, and possibly a promotion piece.

    • Move

      public Move(Square from, Square to)
      Creates a new move, using its origin and destination squares.

      Same as new Move(from, to, Piece.NONE).

      Parameters:
      from - the origin square
      to - the destination square

    • Move

      public Move(Square from, Square to, Piece promotion)
      Creates a new move, defined by its origin square, its destination, and a promotion piece.
      Parameters:
      from - the origin square
      to - the destination square
      promotion - the promotion piece

    • Move

      public Move(String move, Side side)
      Creates a new move using a string representing the coordinates of the origin and destination squares, and possibly a promotion piece. The side is used to disambiguate the color of the promotion piece.

      Valid examples of strings that can be used to instantiate the move are "e2e4", "f1b5" or "a7a8Q".

      Parameters:
      move - the string representing the coordinates of the move
      side - the side used to disambiguate the promotion piece

    • getSan

      public String getSan()
      Returns the Short Algebraic Notation (SAN) of the move, if previously set.
      Returns:
      the representation of the move in SAN notation, or null if not present
      See Also:
      • setSan(String)

    • setSan

      public void setSan(String san)
      Sets the Short Algebraic Notation (SAN) of the move.

      The SAN notation should be set explicitly after the instantiation of the move because it can not be inferred without the full context of the specific position.

      Parameters:
      san - the representation of the move in SAN notation
